ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Seminar style or any style where instructor is paired with a small cohort definitely aid the learning experience of this course.
virtual classes almost every day featuring conversation and other language class stuff. One (or more) asynchronous sessions per week that were mostly worksheets or exams.
We also did some asynchronous activities without attending lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: learn to speak and write basic Japanese
An extremely elementary level of fluency in Japanese, but also the necessary foundation to continue learning the language through a formal education as well as personal studying.
knowledge of Japanese.
Learned the basics of the Japanese language and about the culture.

Even though it's only L1, the amount of new vocabulary we learned is astounding, and you don't realize how much you've learned until you look back at where we all started and then where we were at the end of the semester. You will by no means be fluent, but L1 Japanese will give you a strong basic introductory foundation.

I began to understand and utilize some of the fundamentals of Japanese. Some of the things I practiced include basic conversation stems, grammar structure, how to write Kanji, hiragana, and katakana, and much more.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Specific to my instructor, but better feedback on written assignments would be helpful.
Patience would be helpful, but it is definitely a virtue, as even I found myself dumbfounded at the resistance of students to learn new material.

I did not get any grades in this course throughout the semester. I think this is an issue with the instructor, but the lack of feedback made it really difficult to figure out what was going well and what wasn't.

The class was very interactive and everyone was very cooperative. The faculty is great too. I liked how in class we would spent the time talking and would take home the writing parts, optimizing the limited time we got in class. The clinic helped a lot too.

This course is very hands on and will keep you in your toes with a variety of assignments and material to help with practicing the various concepts covered throughout the class. However, there were some things that worked within an online space better than others, and just due to the nature of the course, I believe it made the course a bit harder.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would be much better if there were more than once a week Japanese Clinic sessions that accompanied this course, as the virtual environment may allow some students to simply wade through class and not participate much. Also, it may speed up class to simply call on students, that way ensuring we all participate and everyone is given a chance to practice.

Latency or audio quality issues are a huge issue in this course due in a way that they are not in others. Very high quality audio is necessary in order to discern nuances and pitch necessary for Japanese, so that is an area that needs improvement if this course is to be taught virtually again.

One thing that I really appreciated was the ability to sign up for a language clinic appointment with a TF to further practice my skills beyond class time, since it helped with boosting my Japanese conversation skills slowly but surely. Another thing that made the course more accessible in this online space was how the professor treated quizzes and other assignments. Initially, we would take the quizzes within class, which didn't exactly work out as intended just due to the nature of zoom. So, she made the quizzes take home and we did them asynchronous to the class session within the time frame allotted, which was really helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If youre trying to learn Japanese then yes, if unsure of the language credit: this language is very hard
Definitely! If a student wishes to take Japanese, this is one of those courses that really will get them started and if they study well may give them a big jumpstart on learning the language.
I would not recommend this course until issues with the virtual setting are fixed and the grading speed is increased so students get real feedback.
If you have genuine interest towards the language and culture, then definitely yes! The class is great! Otherwise dont as it would be a lot of hard work.

If they're interested in learning Japanese, then yes. This course will really teach you and give you a strong basic foundation for further study in the language. However, the workload commitment is high (not difficult, just a lot of work, because learning a new language takes lots of practices), so do keep that in mind.

I would highly recommend taking this course to anyone trying to figure out what language they want to learn. While Japanese is definitely not a very easy language to learn, it is really interesting and fun to practice once you get down the basics, which is a what you focus on in this course. The online setting makes it more difficult and you will need to put in some extra legwork to practice on your own or with other peers in order to get better, but once you look past the difficulty, Japanese can be pretty cool to learn.
